So people with a certain retina disease called retinitis pigmentosa can partly recover their vision thanks to genes from a bacteria. That's called optogenetics. Those genes are transported in neurons by a virus and are then able to create opsins, which are proteins sensitive to light. But those opsins can only sense light on a certain frequency. So the patient had to use specific goggles turning every day light into specific frequency light to make it work. Finally, after 7 months of this treatment, the brain adapted to those new signals coming from the opsins and the patient partly recovered his vision from the one eye that was treated. Got it !
